headline: Not one of my favorite places to work
pros: Work from home. Pay was competitive. Change freeze from mid Nov to Early Jan reduced workload slightly during the holiday season.
cons:
1. Synchrony IT is offshoring TOO MANY JOBS. 
2. Way too many hours. Very common to work 40 hrs on dayshift and another 10-20 at night doing changes or change/troubleshooting support. Week after week.
3. I left after 1 year because I hated it so much. Culture not a fit. 
4. No uniformity of strict change management between departments. Eg...Server team changed stuff on the fly with almost no oversight while Network teams had their changes reviewed scrupulously. Then when stuff broke Network team blamed when it was ALWAYS the server(or application) teams at the root of the problem. 
5. If you are an independent thinker youre not going to like working at Synchrony. If you like being blamed for the problems of other teams, and then required to locate the sources of the problems they caused(of course ALWAYS without root access), under the gun when stuff is broken at 5AM and they start business at 6AM,  you will love being a Network Engineer at Synchrony.

headline: You do not want to work here as a CSR (Customer Service Rep). If you work here, go for a management job.
pros:
Please do not believe the commercials. The only people who may be happy working here are managers.  

Any positive reviews were written by management to make it look like working here is great. 

When the company employees receive the "Great Places To Work" email survey, management forces the employees to take the survey together as a group with the managers to ensure the answers are positive.
cons:
•	If you are one minute late, you will not meet schedule adherence and will be marked negatively.

•	If you have to go into Personal Aux to go use the bathroom, because you’ve been holding your pee and it’s still an hour until your next break, you will not meet schedule adherence and will be marked negatively.

•	If you were about to log out to go to break, lunch or leave for the day and you get the beep indicating a caller is on the line and the call gets complicated and runs over, you have to stay and assist no matter how long it takes and no matter how it may negatively impact your schedule adherence and/or your personal schedule.

•	If you have something come up unexpected, and you have personal business hours but your “unexpected occurrence” isn’t on Synchrony’s approved list of items, then you can’t use your Personal Business time.

•	If you have a family emergency and you’re on the floor/taking calls, your loved ones cannot get a hold of you. You’ll have to wait until your break, lunch and/or end of shift before you can speak with your family. No cell phones are allowed while you're at your desk taking calls.

•	All your calls are recorded and you're being graded based on software that is not 100% reliable. Workstation (the software/program) glitches, shuts down, freezes and overall does not always perform the way it’s supposed to and yet the call center associates metrics and jobs are dependent upon it. If something’s off with Workstation and it messes up the call center associate, the call center associate is in jeopardy vs. management looking further into Workstation and what may be wrong with it. 

•	Management shares that a Customer Service Representative is not here to help customers but to get them off the phone as quickly as possible. We are not here to help but to do what we can to ensure they don’t call again.

•	Your call time is supposed to be 3 mins or less per call. Going through training doesn’t truly represent what will happen on the floor. It’s understood that you can’t train on every single item that may occur but being told that you’ll mainly be taking payments and waiving late fees is false. Most people call because something out of the norm is going on and they need help. So most calls are not simple which means your call time will typically be long. 

•	Important updates that involve changes in processes are sent via email and then the Customer Service Representative is expected to read  these communications and keep up to date while continuing to take calls and always be up to date on what’s changed. Sometimes the changes are a little complex and additional training would be beneficial. Sometimes there’s off phone training but most of the times there’s not. 

•	Taking verbal abuse from customers and having to remain calm and being forced to read from a script or potentially face termination if you allow your feelings (that are rightly felt when someone is treating you like dirt) to
get the best of the situation. 

•	Customer Service Reps are expected to be IT experts but are not paid extra for it. Each client should have a Digital Tech team but they don't. Customer Service Reps are supposed to have low call times and yet when someone calls and needs someone to hold their hand as they try to register their card, or set up Auto Pay, or is having overall IT related issues with an App or with getting into their account…the Customer Service Representative  is stuck on the call until the customer gets access. You cannot have low call times and help people with IT and online/eservice matters. 

•	Dealing with Multi Client Schedule Bid process. Upon being hired, you don’t really get to pick a schedule that truly works for you; you have to select from what’s available. When you get that schedule, it is not permanent. During the Multi-Client Schedule Bid time, every person is ranked and depending on your rank order, you are scheduled to select from an entire new list of schedules (your current schedule may not be on the new schedule bid list) and by the time you get to select, what’s left may not work for you. If you have to make it work, you’ll have to rearrange your childcare, any scheduled doctor’s appointments, etc. If you can’t make it work, you have to resign and it’s a great way for them not to have to
perform layoffs and potentially be on the line for any earned unemployment benefits.

headline: "Abandon hope all ye who enter..."
pros: The seldom realization that you have a choice to leave the company, and are not trapped by the exorbitant amount of paid time off.
cons:
The interview process at Synchrony is an elaborate ruse to promote a diverse workforce. We focus so much on inclusiveness because it is only accolade Synchrony is continually recognized for. It is a counter-intuitive practice, in that some certainly deserve and are qualified to be in the position that they are in, but they did not get to that position based off value. The interview process itself remains completely unchanged, even after we have claimed to have fixed it; in whole it is a disengaged, robotic charade. Synchrony allows initiatives to be in place to promote people based on diversity, not merit. 

Synchrony’s agenda to promote for diversity vs. competence will inevitably cause more harm than good. Putting lesser-qualified candidates in positions that could be better performed by someone else causes continuous management issues and a lack of faith in senior leadership. There are numerous studies detailing how it is impossible to hire both for competency and diversity initiatives concurrently, so the fact that Synchrony acts as if both are in place highlights our obliviousness.     

This is the root cause of 95% of our problems here, yet we choose to continue full-steam ahead with this hushed initiative. I’m not sure if senior leadership thinks we are too thoughtless to realize what is actually happening or afraid to say so, but that is not the case. Everyone knows we are promoting under qualified minorities over those better suited for jobs. 

I’m certain nothing will be done to improve our interview process because Synchrony cares more about appearing successful than setting themselves up for success. You would think that after losing our biggest client after a decade’s long relationship we would realize our error. Walmart chose to leave us because we are years behind on technological advances and have exemplified a stagnancy to change. How do we ever expect to get ahead if we continue this same path of complacency and ignorance?

headline: Business Leadership Program
pros: The nice thing about BLP was the the amount of capital they invested into recent college grads to enhance technical skills for certain areas (I.e financial modeling courses, coding courses, sales force trainings.) In addition, you did have high more exposure to senior leaders, but at the end of the day that access didn’t really add that much additional take way value to the program. Yes, the CFO or CCO knew who you were, but that didn’t necessarily help you on program. Could be extremely beneficial if you stay at SYF for a long period of time.
cons:
BLPs toward the end of the program aren’t paid fairly or based truly on Merit/ level of work/ responsibility  post program. As someone who went through the program and received the highest merit rankings, the difference between you and an average performing BLP is just a few hundred dollars in total pay at the end. Doesn’t incentivize a BLP to stay. The program management also lacks transparency and often waits until last minute to explain very important details that affect you in a big way ( I.e. they tell you a month before you move across the country when they’ve known for the last 3 that you’re doing it.... just to be fair to everyone in program rather than rational). This lack of urgency is very frustrating  when trying to find housing for each rotation.

Finally, industry isn’t the most appealing outside of the IT function.

headline: Great Entry Level Experience with Ability to Grow
pros:
Synchrony is a great place to get the best call center experience. The company strives for great customer experiences. Great in-depth training when you start. I've always had great managers and peers. You are provided with everything to do your job well. Several opportunities to Grow -- leadership programs, projects, Affinity groups, free training workshops, plus tuition reimbursement. 

There is a great level of transparency in management and senior leaders. We've had a lot of organizational changes when Synchrony separated from GE and all the expectations of your role in the company is always clear.

Solid pay for entry level jobs with opportunites for advancement and with it being an international company you have the chance to relocate if you'd want. Top benefits with insurance (health insurance dental and vision). 2 weeks off and 12 additional floating days to start plus illness and business time off allotments. Sites have gyms or you can get fitness reimbursement. Healthy commitments like healthy foods in cafeteria sports activities like softball, and groups like weight watchers are there to help. 

Depending on your department there are a lot of ways to get recognized for working hard. Plus many on the phone roles are bonus eligible paid out monthly.
cons: Working on the phones can be tough. It's easy to feel overwhelmed or stressed. Sometimes managers seem nonchalant to resolve issues you are seeing or having. It's not uncommon to have miscommunication especially between other offices. It takes a lot of dedication to get the skills needed to succeed or find a spot thats a good fit for you. Pay is better for newly hired associated than more seniored associates who were overlooked at the last pay raise. It also seems people can skid by the rules and there are no consequences which can bring down morale. Inconsistency to the rules can cause tension in the workplace from time to time.

headline: Customer Service Job at Synchrony Shawnee, KS
pros:
Pay was decent at 11 an hour for basic starting call center CS work,  
There is a small gym on site, a cafeteria during the normal day shift, 14 days of vacation a year starting with  floating holidays and additionally sick days,  And a small break room upstairs with free coffee/tea and vending machines.  401k match was 4% then, good health/vision/dental benefits starting day 1

Medical benefits on day 1.  When i was there 4-5 weeks of actual training with full pay.  Incentive bonuses after 6 months probation if you meet call metrics.  
-Ability for promotion that is encouraged within the company after 6 months.  Management is generally friendly, though they expect timeliness and that you comply to your schedule. 

 As a customer service rep, you have a decent level of autonomy to fix and resolve problems for customers and correct errors or provide some financial recompense for inconvenience or errors, had to escalate calls maybe once every other day.  

Standards are clear and consistent. .  Relatively good about time off if asked for early enough in advance.  Relatively relaxed dress code, unless management is visiting, ie public school dress code, nothing offensive or torn.

Generally found it easy work, but better opportunities came along and I'm not a big customer service job fan.
cons:
You'll be dealing with phone customers for 8-10 hrs a day (over 40hr week overtime pay, not mandatory) and people are usually not calling because its a good day. 

The work can be rather boring and rote.  
Staffing levels vary as new accounts come on or new corporate customers.  
Some days it slow and people have the opportunity(by choice) to go home early, other days it's back to back calls.  The longer you're there the more account types you handle,

You have scheduled breaks for lunch and two other times during a shift (bathroom at will of course), so if you don't like sitting, can be frustrating. (encouraged and expected to take breaks at scheduled times as part of metrics)

headline: World-class spinoff from a world-class company
pros:
Great senior leadership and management when it was under GE Capital. Many of the senior leaders remain, so I'd assume that the GE culture has carried over. There's really a culture of leadership and professional development here with Leadership 360's and leadership training. HR and your managers often have proactive discussions with you when it comes to career development. Obviously, you still have to drive your own career, but they certainly provide the resources, training and assuming that you perform well, the opportunities, as well. There's an emphasis on rounding out your skill sets to position you for "that next job."

Other pros:
1) Well-developed business processes in place, such as the 1 and 3-year strategic planning reviews.
2) Great sense of camaraderie across the functions. Everyone is generally willing to help and support you. It feels like an army marching to the beat of the same drum. 
3) The Marketing function really drives the bus here, but there are healthy debates with the other functions (Risk, Finance, Legal, etc.)
4) Compensation is competitive. Health insurance could've been better.
5) Good work-life balance. Ability to work from home occasionally.
cons:
1) Since the company is so mature, they are not always the first to innovate, but once they put their resources behind an initiative, they can play catch-up quickly. 
2) Be prepared to possibly move every few years in order to move ahead in your career. Synchrony's approach of having teams co-located with their clients means that there are many smaller teams scattered across the country. Additionally, there are major HQ offices and centers of excellence in Connecticut, Ohio, Georgia and Illinois.

headline: Avoid like the plague!
pros: Benefit package, location, cafeteria on site.
cons:
Everything else. I worked for Synchrony when it was still GE Financial from 2007-2011. It was the worst 4 years of my life. I'm not sure now why I tried to hard to get the job. They jerked me around from the start. I had temped there for one day years prior and passed. So when I took the test for the job (which was a joke) they had to do additional processing or some garbage and it took them almost  2 months to get back to me with my results. I should have taken that as a sign from the start.

It was great at first. Great benefits, decent entry pay for someone with only an Associates Degree, a second shift schedule that didn't make me get up early. I loved my first supervisor. But then shift bid happened and I was moved to a new supervisor who was a jerk. I started getting write ups because my call handle times were too long. I was told I "helped too much". I'm sorry, but I thought  customer service was about resolving the customer's issues? Not there! I had 10 years of customer service experience and an AS degree in Business Administration before I set foot in there, but they didn't care. They want you to get the customer off the phone as quick as possible. It's not about helping, it's about handling the most calls. My quality scores were PERFECT, but I took too long. I eventually transferred to Store so my handle time went down. Then I got sick, and things really went downhill. They were not at all flexible in letting me take sick time that I had. I was written up for BEING IN THE HOSPITAL. When I had to be off work for surgery I had to jump through a million hoops to have my disability leave approved and ultimately someone at their disability center who wasn't even a doctor made the determination to allow me time off, not my doctor. It was a joke. I was eventually fired. Hilarious, since I was one of the few on my team that actually did the job - you know, answering the required number of calls, getting the required quality score, and helping the customer.

headline: Disengage
pros:
I don't work there anymore and I'm thankful that my days at SynBnk are over.  That is the best thing about this employer.  I'm so glad I don't have to go back, as it was one of the worst experiences of my entire life (and I've been through some very difficult times).  

I have been meaning to write this review for a very long time, but just thinking about SynBnk put me in a bad mood.  I'd get angry and upset all over again while trying to write about that horrible place.  I'm at a wonderful job now and enough time has passed that I can finally write this.  If it convinces even one person to NOT apply for a job with SynBnk, then it's worth it!
cons:
There are many reasons why the turnover rate at this place is so high.  There are back to back training classes, yet rows upon rows of empty desks.  Some people quit during training, once they realize what a horrible place they've signed up with. 

Every day on local talk radio, there's an ad played regarding open positions at SynBnk and I know it means they're still understaffed.  I smile every time I hear it because I know I'm driving to a job that I love, and NOT to SynBnk. 

I will list some specific cons, but I'm only scratching the surface here.

*Employees are made to feel that they are constantly on the verge of being fired, no matter how good they are at the job.  Even "star" employees will up and rage quit in the middle of the day.

*Favoritism is a problem.  Suddenly there's new positions custom-created for a select few people.

*Disciplinary action is constantly taken against people for the dumbest of reasons.  Each disciplinary action sticks with you for ONE ENTIRE YEAR, no matter how insignificant the "violation" was.  

*There is no room for cutting anyone some slack, no matter what the circumstances were.  It doesn't matter if you or your child had an emergency; the rules are the RULES and everyone must abide by them.  

*Examples of things people were disciplined for, that I know of:  using the f-word while on lunch break, across the street while talking to a friend in a casual conversation, where no customers could've overheard; being 1 minute late clocking in or out; using your sick day benefit for what they deem is too many times even though you have enough hours; etc.

*Policies are explained in the most vague way possible.  If you ask for clarification, you'll find that different co-workers are given different answers from different managers.  Yet, you are held responsible for following all the policies and it's your fault if you interpreted the written guidelines differently than how the person punishing you saw them.

*When a new process or procedure or anything comes out, they're fond of tacking this phrase to the end of it:  "failure to comply will result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination."  Am I just there to be punished, or am I at work??!!

*You are micro-manged to death.

*You are not treated like an adult, but as a misbehaving child 

*You have to stick to corporate-approved scripts while on calls, and some of them contain lies.

*Not only does management treat employees horrible, but the company as a whole treats customers horrible.  You only needs to look at BBB's site to see proof of what I'm talking about.

*Even if logical reason led you to believe that the person on the phone was an ID thief, you were not allowed to act based on evidence or your own thinking skills.  Rather, you had to "follow the process."  If the ID thief could pass the screening tests, then they could get away with doing whatever they wanted to do.  

*"Following the process" per company rules and regulations could leave actual cardholders stranded,or repeatedly unable to use their cards despite making the same kinds of purchases at the same kinds of merchants.  

*Having to participate in treating customers so poorly (or else I'd get fired)  HONESTLY had me in tears after work some days.   

*Every negative comment I've read about SynBnk on Glassdoor is 100% true.  I still feel I've listed the bare minimum.  Basically, avoid this place like the plague.

headline: Business Leadership Program
pros:
The BLP program is really an honor to be in. They take awesome care of you and really want to see you succeed. It is a fast-track to higher leadership roles in the company. There is unbelievable exposure to senior management, most assignment leaders are at VP level or higher. We had dinner with the CEO and other senior leaders on the first night. People at all levels of the company are approachable and friendly. 

There are lots of opportunities for travel and explore different parts of the business. Rotations are every 8 months and you can pretty much go anywhere in the US to explore the different parts of the business. Relocation benefits are generous. 

Salary and benefits are extremely good, especially for a first job out of college. I haven't heard of any salaries for first jobs which are as generous as Synchrony. 

It seems like they took the best of the GE leadership programs and even made it better. I see this program getting more and more competitive in upcoming years, but so far it's been great! They really want to see you succeed and the program is well respected throughout the company.
cons: Since it's a new program there are a few kinks still being worked out- but it's only going to improve in upcoming years. Because the company is so diverse and spread out throughout the country, communication can take extra effort - meetings are usually done over the phone and not in person.

headline: Fraud Division
pros:
There are not a lot of typical pros for working at Synchrony Financial. They did recently add a "coffee" station in although they had to add a disclaimer sign indicating it was not made from actual coffee. The work is consistent. Always at least a 40 hour work week to complete under normal circumstances.

Healthcare used to be good. It's not anymore.
cons:
Working in conjunction with peers to solve major issues is discouraged. The rules and requirements of the job change every day but the software used to do the work is 10-20 years old.   Shooting the messenger is a common tactic. Trying to go above and beyond in your role is strongly discouraged across all areas of the business. Stay in your box and keep your head down. Analytical people need not apply. Sadly because the business does not promote people who are analytical upper management is full of individuals incapable of adapting and creating solutions. 

Work and family is something that is preached about. It does not exist here. Any deviation from the set schedule will land a person on the fast track to write ups.

Compensation is poor, advancement is negligible.

cons: As a relatively new employee, I haven't yet experienced cons with the company.  I've heard a few coworkers mention wishing there was a café on site.  As with most call centers, tight attendance guidelines make it more likely that workers will come to work sick. That 'con' is prevalent with any work position that requires good attendance, though.

headline: Crushingly disappointing
pros: Pleasant people, nice building, free snacks, free coffee, occasional free pizza, management is considerate
cons:
-If you are under the age of 45 walk away. They can use the brand name of their old parent company for another three years to sucker in new grads and they will. This company recently spun off and they're a bit of a mess. 

-Understaffed and at the same time bloated with employees who coasted through when this company was with GE. The best GE employees (there were a lot of them) bailed out before this company split away. Synchrony legacy employees haven't bothered to further their education in decades. It's going to show now that they have to ramp up IT project work/ finance platforms and can't rely on their parent company anymore for brand name and support. The IT platforms they do have are archaic, it will stay this way because legacy employees  jobs depend on them not having to learn new languages/ systems

-Trying to be hip and have a startup atmosphere. (In a patronizing and ham-handed attempt to attract "millennials" they quickly set up an "innovation station" complete with an indoor putting green) now that they desperately need younger people- don't fall for it, the support and manpower just isn't there and they backed the wrong horse when it's comes to mobile payment platforms

-Most employees are generally nice but have zero candor, creativity, and judgement. They honestly just want to coast through the day and go home to their families. For a younger person eager to role up their sleeves and build something this is crushing. For a company recently gone public, it will really slow them down. 

-They try to position themselves as an analytics and marketing company, at the end of the day they are still a low tier credit card company that targets people with the lowest credit quality relative to other lenders. Their collection methods and platforms give them terrible reputation and it shows even more without the GE brand name 

-North Stamford location very far from metro north, (move the HQ! You're a new company now!!) I mention this because it can't be helping with retention of new talent they need badly
